message.content:
Implement the following plan: # Hero Section Rewrite — Exact Mockup Match ## Context The current hero has three critical problems vs the reference mockup: 1. **Papers look like flat UI cards** — rounded corners, landscape orientation, uniform grey lines, weak shadows 2. **Spheres look like flat coloured circles** — need true 3D glass with specular highlights and depth 3. **Chart card shouldn't exist** — the mockup has ONLY papers + spheres. No separate chart element. The mockup's visual identity is sold by **lighting and shadows**: a directional light from upper-left creates long soft shadows on the pages and bright specular highlights on the spheres. ## Files to Modify (2 files) | # | File | Change | |---|------|--------| | 1 | `apps/web/app/globals.css` | Update `.paper-shadow`, fix `float-thesis` keyframe | | 2 | `apps/web/components/landing/hero-section.tsx` | Full rewrite of right zone | --- ## Detailed Visual Analysis of Mockup ### Papers (3 scattered thesis pages — with natural folds/curls) | Property | Mockup | Current (broken) | |----------|--------|------------------| | Shape | **Tall portrait** (~220×340px), sharp corners (2px radius) | Landscape-ish cards, `rounded-xl` | | Content | Dense paragraph-like text: title line + grouped line blocks separated by whitespace gaps, looks like real paragraphs | Single list of uniform grey lines | | Shadows | **Deep directional** — shifted down-right (12px, 30px), large blur (60px), 20%+ opacity. This is the #1 visual seller | Weak centered shadow | | 3D tilt | Heavy rotation -15° to +5° | Similar range but less dramatic because pages are short | | Stacking | Pages overlap significantly, centre page on top | OK but pages too short to overlap well | | **Paper curl/fold** | Pages are NOT flat — they have natural bends and rolling like real paper caught mid-air. One page curls at the bottom, another has a slight roll at the edge, some appear to bend slightly in the middle | Completely flat rectangles | #### CSS technique for paper curls/folds Real paper curling can be simulated with multiple CSS techniques combined: 1. **Page curl at corner** — a pseudo-element (`::after`) with a gradient fold triangle + matching shadow 2. **Subtle body warp** — CSS `perspective` + `rotateX`/`rotateY` on the page to make it appear to tilt away from the viewer 3. **Edge roll** — A thin strip along one edge that uses a gradient from white to slightly darker (simulating paper rolling over) 4. **Shadow that follows the curl** — `filter: drop-shadow()` on the parent (not `box-shadow`) so the shadow follows the non-rectangular silhouette created by the curl 5. **Multiple box-shadow layers** — The main page shadow + a separate darker contact shadow near the curl point ### Glass Spheres (8-12 spheres) | Property | Mockup | Current (broken) | |----------|--------|------------------| | 3D effect | **Radial gradient with specular highlight** — bright white spot at ~30% 25% of sphere, base colour in middle, darker at edges | Flat `bg-gradient-to-br` — looks like a coloured disc | | CSS technique | `radial-gradient(circle at 30% 25%, white-highlight, transparent, base-color, dark-edge)` | Linear gradient | | Sizes | Biggest ~90px, range down to 15px | Max 80px, range too narrow | | Clustering | Grape-like tight bunch, spheres genuinely overlap | Spread too far apart | | Position | Right of pages, partially overlapping rightmost page edge | Too far right, isolated | ### Chart Card **Does not exist in mockup.** Remove entirely. --- ## Implementation ### 1. `globals.css` — Update shadows, curls, float-thesis **`.paper-page`** — uses `filter: drop-shadow()` so shadow follows rotated/curled shape: ```css .paper-page { filter: drop-shadow(10px 25px 30px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.22)) drop-shadow(4px 10px 12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.10)); } ``` **`.paper-shadow`** — keep as supplemental contact shadow: ```css .paper-shadow { box-shadow: 8px 20px 40px -10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.18), 3px 8px 16px -5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.10); } ``` **`.paper-curl-corner`** — bottom-right corner fold: ```css .paper-curl-corner { position: relative; } .paper-curl-corner::after { content: ''; position: absolute; bottom: 0; right: 0; width: 45px; height: 45px; background: linear-gradient(225deg, #E0E0E0 0%, #EEEEEE 40%, white 50%, transparent 50%); border-radius: 0 0 3px 0; box-shadow: -3px -3px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.06); } ``` **`.paper-curl-bottom`** — subtle bottom edge darkening (roll): ```css .paper-curl-bottom::after { content: ''; position: absolute; bottom: 0; left: 0; right: 0; height: 8px; background: linear-gradient(to bottom, transparent, rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04)); border-radius: 0 0 3px 3px; } ``` **`.paper-curl-side`** — right edge shadow strip (lift): ```css .paper-curl-side::after { content: ''; position: absolute; top: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0; width: 8px; background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent, rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)); border-radius: 0 3px 3px 0; } ``` **`@keyframes float-thesis`** — Y-only float (rotation stays from inline transform): ```css @keyframes float-thesis { 0%, 100% { transform: translateY(0); } 50% { transform: translateY(-14px); } } ``` ### 2. `hero-section.tsx` — Rewrite right zone #### Remove - `GlassChart` component and its entire motion.div — **deleted** - Current `TextLines` component — replaced with `ParagraphBlock` #### New: `ParagraphBlock` component Simulates a real paragraph — 3-5 lines of varying width, thin (`h-[1.5px]`), with natural variation: ```tsx function ParagraphBlock({ widths }: { widths: string[] }) { return (
{widths.map((w, i) => (
))}
); } ``` #### New: `ThesisPage` component A tall portrait page that looks like actual paper **with natural folds/curls**: **Base structure:** - Size: fixed width + tall aspect. Example: `w-[230px]` with tall content making it ~320px+ - Corners: `rounded-[3px]` — almost sharp, like real paper - Colour: `bg-white` - Internal content: title line (`h-[2.5px] w-[50%] bg-[#B0B0B0]`) + 3 ParagraphBlocks with `gap-[12px]` - Outer wrapper uses `filter: drop-shadow(...)` instead of `box-shadow` — so shadow follows the curled silhouette **Paper curl/fold effects (3 variants, one per page):** **Variant A — bottom-right corner curl:** - `::after` pseudo-element: positioned `absolute bottom-0 right-0`, size ~40×40px - Background: `linear-gradient(225deg, #E8E8E8 0%, #F5F5F5 45%, transparent 50%)` — simulates folded-back paper - The main page gets `border-bottom-right-radius: 40px` where the curl is, OR clip-path to cut the corner - Shadow under the curl: a small `box-shadow` on the pseudo-element shifted left-up **Variant B — bottom edge roll (gentle wave):** - A thin `::after` strip along the bottom: `h-[6px]`, full width - Background: `linear-gradient(to bottom, transparent, rgba(0,0,0,0.04))` — subtle darkening simulating paper rolling - Combined with slight `rotateX(2deg)` on the page to make it look like the bottom is lifting toward the viewer **Variant C — side edge lift:** - Right edge appears to lift: achieved by combining `rotateY(-4deg)` with the parent perspective - A thin shadow gradient along the right edge: `linear-gradient(to right, transparent 90%, rgba(0,0,0,0.04))` - This makes the page appear to curl away at the right edge **Shadow strategy for all pages:** - **Primary**: `filter: drop-shadow(10px 25px 30px rgba(0,0,0,0.20))` on the outer container — follows the rotated shape - **Contact shadow**: additional `box-shadow: 5px 15px 20px -5px rgba(0,0,0,0.12)` for a tighter shadow near the page - Using `filter: drop-shadow` rather than `box-shadow` alone is critical — `box-shadow` creates a rectangular shadow regardless of rotation, while `drop-shadow` follows the actual rendered shape #### Three pages layout (absolute positioned in right zone): ``` Page A (back-left, corner curl): - rotate: -15deg - position: left: 4%, top: 10% - width: 230px - z-index: 1 - animationDelay: 0s - Curl: bottom-right corner fold - Lines: title + three 4-line paragraphs Page B (centre-front, bottom roll, on top): - rotate: -6deg, rotateX: 2deg (subtle lift) - position: left: 16%, top: 0% - width: 250px - z-index: 3 - animationDelay: 1.5s - Curl: bottom edge roll - Lines: title + three 5-line paragraphs Page C (right-lean, side lift): - rotate: 5deg, rotateY: -3deg - position: left: 32%, top: 16% - width: 210px - z-index: 2 - animationDelay: 3s - Curl: right edge lift - Lines: title + two 4-line paragraphs ``` #### New: `GlassSphere` component The critical 3D glass effect via **radial gradient with specular highlight**: ```tsx function GlassSphere({ size, baseColor, darkColor, top, left, delay, opacity = 1 }: { size: number; baseColor: string; // e.g. "122,140,102" — RGB values darkColor: string; // e.g. "80,100,60" top: number; left: number; delay: string; opacity?: number; }) { return (
); } ``` The `radial-gradient(circle at 30% 25%, ...)` places a bright white specular highlight in the upper-left where the light hits, then fades through transparent into the sphere's base colour, with a darker edge at the bottom-right. This creates the 3D glass illusion. #### Sphere Cluster — 10 spheres All within a `relative` container positioned at `right: -2%, top: 3%, z-index: 4`: ``` # Size Top Left Base RGB Dark RGB Delay 1 90 0 30 122,140,102 80,100,60 0s ← big sage 2 72 55 110 196,147,90 160,110,55 0.8s ← big amber 3 62 100 10 232,220,200 200,185,160 1.4s ← large cream 4 50 25 130 168,184,148 130,150,110 1.2s ← med sage 5 42 135 90 140,160,120 100,120,80 0.6s ← med olive 6 30 155 45 58,58,58 30,30,30 2.0s ← sm charcoal 7 26 75 0 196,147,90 160,110,55 2.4s ← sm amber 8 34 175 120 232,220,200 200,185,160 1.6s ← sm cream 9 20 95 160 122,140,102 80,100,60 1.8s ← tiny sage 10 16 190 70 240,230,214 210,200,180 0.4s ← tiny cream ``` Container size: `w-[200px] h-[240px]` #### Right zone container ```tsx
``` The `perspective: 1200px` on the parent makes the child rotations look 3D rather than just skewed. #### Motion entrances (staggered) - Pages: delay 0.5s, 0.65s, 0.8s — fade in + scale 0.88→1 + y: 40→0 - Spheres: delay 0.9s — fade in + scale 0.7→1 - (No chart — removed) --- ## Verification 1. `pnpm tsc --noEmit` — zero errors 2. Visual: pages are tall portrait shapes with sharp corners, dense paragraph-like content 3. Visual: pages have deep directional shadows shifted down-right 4. Visual: spheres have bright white specular highlight in upper-left, dark edge bottom-right = 3D glass 5. Visual: no chart card present — only papers and spheres 6. Visual: spheres cluster tightly, overlapping each other and the rightmost page edge 7. Visual: entire composition forms one cohesive cluster, not separate groups If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/devs/.REDACTED.jsonl

`::after` pseudo-element: positioned `absolute bottom-0 right-0`, size ~40×40px - Background: `linear-gradient(225deg, #E8E8E8 0%, #F5F5F5 45%, transparent 50%)` — simulates folded-back paper - The main page gets `border-bottom-right-radius: 40px` where the curl is, OR clip-path to cut the corner - Combined with slight `rotateX(2deg)` on the page to make it look like the bottom is lifting toward the viewer **Variant C — side edge lift:** - Right edge appears to lift: achieved by combining `rotateY(-4deg)` with the parent perspective - A thin shadow gradient along the right edge: `linear-gradient(to right, transparent 90%, rgba(0,0,0,0.04))` - This makes the page appear to curl away at the right edge **Shadow strategy for all pages:** - **Primary**: `filter: drop-shadow(10px 25px 30px rgba(0,0,0,0.20))` on the outer container — follows the rotated shape - **Contact shadow**: additional `box-shadow: 5px 15px 20px -5px rgba(0,0,0,0.12)` for a tighter shadow near the page - Using `filter: drop-shadow` rather than `box-shadow` alone is critical — `box-shadow` creates a rectangular shadow regardless of rotation, while `drop-shadow` follows the actual rendered shape #### Three pages layout (absolute positioned in right zone): ``` Page A (back-left, corner curl): - rotate: -15deg - position: left: 4%, top: 10% - width: 230px - z-index: 1 - animationDelay: 0s - Curl: bottom-right corner fold - Lines: title + three 4-line paragraphs Page B (centre-front, bottom roll, on top): - rotate: -6deg, rotateX: 2deg (subtle lift) - position: left: 16%, top: 0% - width: 250px - z-index: 3 - animationDelay: 1.5s - Curl: bottom edge roll - Lines: title + three 5-line paragraphs Page C (right-lean, side lift): - rotate: 5deg, rotateY: -3deg - position: left: 32%, top: 16% - width: 210px - z-index: 2 - animationDelay: 3s - Curl: right edge lift - Lines: title + two 4-line paragraphs ``` #### New: `GlassSphere` component The critical 3D glass effect via **radial gradient with specular highlight**: ```tsx function GlassSphere({ size, baseColor, darkColor, top, left, delay, opacity = 1 }: { size: number; baseColor: string; // e.g. "122,140,102" — RGB values darkColor: string; // e.g. "80,100,60" top: number; left: number; delay: string; opacity?: number; }) { return (
); } ``` The `radial-gradient(circle at 30% 25%, ...)` places a bright white specular highlight in the upper-left where the light hits, then fades through transparent into the sphere's base colour, with a darker edge at the bottom-right. This creates the 3D glass illusion. #### Sphere Cluster — 10 spheres All within a `relative` container positioned at `right: -2%, top: 3%, z-index: 4`: ``` # Size Top Left Base RGB Dark RGB Delay 1 90 0 30 122,140,102 80,100,60 0s ← big sage 2 72 55 110 196,147,90 160,110,55 0.8s ← big amber 3 62 100 10 232,220,200 200,185,160 1.4s ← large cream 4 50 25 130 168,184,148 130,150,110 1.2s ← med sage 5 42 135 90 140,160,120 100,120,80 0.6s ← med olive 6 30 155 45 58,58,58 30,30,30 2.0s ← sm charcoal 7 26 75 0 196,147,90 160,110,55 2.4s ← sm amber 8 34 175 120 232,220,200 200,185,160 1.6s ← sm cream 9 20 95 160 122,140,102 80,100,60 1.8s ← tiny sage 10 16 190 70 240,230,214 210,200,180 0.4s ← tiny cream ``` Container size: `w-[200px] h-[240px]` #### Right zone container ```tsx
``` The `perspective: 1200px` on the parent makes the child rotations look 3D rather than just skewed. #### Motion entrances (staggered) - Pages: delay 0.5s, 0.65s, 0.8s — fade in + scale 0.88→1 + y: 40→0 - Spheres: delay 0.9s — fade in + scale 0.7→1 - (No chart — removed) --- ## Verification 1. `pnpm tsc --noEmit` — zero errors 2. Based on the search results, here's what I found about creating CSS photorealistic 3D glass sphere effects:

## Key Techniques for CSS Glass Sphere Effects

CSS sphere collections provide a complete guide to creating ultra-realistic three-dimensional sphere effects and complex geometry purely with CSS.

### Core Methods

Depth and dynamic lighting can be achieved without traditional 3D tools, using a combination of radial gradients, box-shadow, and CSS Houdini @property for smooth shadow animation.

For creating realistic sphere effects specifically, the effect is achieved through gradients (radial-gradient), shadows (box-shadow), pseudo-elements (::before, ::after) for highlights and shadows, and dynamic variables (@property) for animation.

### Multiple Layers Approach

To create a more realistic looking ball, multiple gradients can be added using pseudo-elements to simulate two light sources. Additionally, ambient light scattering toward the limb of the sphere is best simulated by a second overlay with its background-image set to a black radial-gradient with varying transparency.

### Glass-Like Specular Highlights

The bright spot caused by specular reflection can be created as white at the center with transparency increasing with distance.

## Recent Resources (2025)

Recent CSS sphere collections from September 2025 provide comprehensive guides to creating ultra-realistic three-dimensional sphere effects purely with CSS.

These techniques combine multiple radial gradients layered together to create the photorealistic glass sphere effect you're looking for.

## Spline Overview

Spline is a free 3D design software with real-time collaboration to create web interactive experiences in the browser. It's a free, real-time collaborative 3D design tool to create interactive experiences within the browser with easy 3D animations, models, and textures.

## Hero Section Integration

Spline's real superpower is the native Webflow integration—drop your 3D scenes directly into Webflow pages with full animation control over scroll, click, and hover triggers. Additionally, you can create eye-catching 3D hero sections that respond to mouse movement or scroll and export as an embed to drop into Webflow, Framer, or custom sites.

## Glass and Material Design

For glass elements specifically, glass elements like soft body hover effects and animated glass elements can be designed synced with user actions.

## Performance Considerations for 2025-2026

Heavy 3D bundle size tanks Core Web Vitals, so the solution is to use no-code tools like Spline (which optimize automatically) or use web frameworks' lazy-loading features. Lightweight frameworks such as Spline and React Three Fiber make it easy to build 3D environments that move, tilt, and react to the user.

The search results show that Spline is well-positioned as a performant solution for 2025-2026 web design projects involving interactive 3D elements.

I've performed a web search on CSS 3D transforms for creating realistic paper curl effects with perspective and shadows. Here are the key findings:

## CSS 3D Transform Techniques for Paper Curl Effects

Paper curls create a natural-looking slightly curved box effect that's an optical illusion created by a shadow at the bottom of the element.

### Core Approach

Creating a paper curl effect involves creating a container for your element with relative position and overflow set to hidden, then creating a pseudo-element using the ::before selector with absolute position transformed using rotate and skew methods to create the curl effect.

### Shadow and Depth

You need to add a box-shadow to give the curl some depth, and add a linear gradient to the pseudo-element to create the illusion of a page curl.

### Perspective Implementation

To establish a realistic 3D viewing context, use the perspective property which is essential for accurate depth perception, along with transform-style: preserve-3d to ensure nested elements exist correctly within the same coordinate space.

If you use a smaller perspective value like 200, the element appears up close and the effect appears more prominent, whereas a greater value like 1000 shifts your view farther away and makes the effect less prominent.

### Customization

You can customize the paper curl effect by adjusting the values in the CSS properties, changing the size and position of the curl by adjusting transform values, and changing the color and intensity of the shadow by adjusting box-shadow properties.

The search results provide practical examples and technical guidance from recent resources including materials from 2024 and early 2026.

- box-shadow creates rectangular shadows even on rotated elements

- No real paper texture/grain

I've performed the web search for your query about @react-three/drei components. Here are the results:

## Key Findings:

**@react-three/drei Package**: The latest version is 10.7.7, last published 3 months ago.

**Float Component**: Float creates an animation with properties for speed (animation speed, defaults to 1), rotationIntensity (XYZ rotation intensity, defaults to 1), and floatIntensity (up/down float intensity, defaults to 1).

**MeshTransmissionMaterial**: MeshTransmissionMaterial is a special material that allows light to pass through 3D objects, creating a glass-like, transparent effect, with parameters such as sampling, thickness, and chromatic aberration for fine-tuning visual effects.

**Environment Component**: The Environment helper produces a great effect and is much easier to use than manually setting scene.environment properties. A list of presets can be found at https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/blob/master/src/helpers/env

**ContactShadows**: The ContactShadows component generates shadows under objects, adding depth and a sense of space to the scene. ContactShadows has parameters like opacity, scale, blur, far, and resolution, and can be optimized to render only when objects are static.

For practical examples, you can explore CodeSandbox which has an online playground for viewing and forking @react-three/drei example apps and templates.

I've found comprehensive information about setting up react-three-fiber with Next.js 15 and the App Router. Here are the key findings:

## React Three Fiber Compatibility with Next.js 15

R3F v8 is not compatible with React 19 or Next 15, which uses React 19. Use the R3F v9 RC instead which can be installed with @react-three/fiber@rc.

## Dynamic Import with SSR: false

For implementing react-three-fiber components in Next.js 15 App Router, you can import the whole component that uses threejs while skipping SSR using `dynamic(() => import('../components/C'), { ssr: false })`.

However, there's an important breaking change: Disallow using ssr: false option with next/dynamic in Server Components. This means you'll need to use this pattern within client components, not server components.

## Recommended Setup Pattern

You can dynamically import the component with `ssr: false`, and optionally add a loading component to show while the component loads on the client. The basic pattern is:

```javascript
import dynamic from 'next/dynamic';

const DynamicComponent = dynamic(
  () => import('../components/YourR3FComponent'),
  { ssr: false }
);
```

## Additional Configuration

It should work out of the box but you will encounter untranspiled add-ons in the three.js ecosystem, in which case you need to add three to transpilePackages property in next.config.js.

The search results confirm these are recent best practices as of January 2025-February 2026, aligned with the current Next.js 15 and React 19 release cycle.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding three.js bundle size impact with react-three-fiber and tree shaking performance in 2025:

## Bundle Size Impact

The minified and gzipped bundle size of Three.js comes in at approximately 170kB, compared to Babylon.js at 1.4MB, making Three.js relatively lightweight for 3D graphics. However, Three.module.js has a stat size of 1.23 MB with a parsed size of 658 KB and gzip size of 155 KB.

## Tree Shaking Limitations

A significant challenge with Three.js is that Three.js is quite heavy and tree-shaking doesn't yet yield the results you would hope for. However, you can always create your own export-file and alias "three" towards it to work around this limitation.

## Best Practices for Optimization

To improve bundle size and performance:

- Avoid importing unused modules such as examples/jsm/controls/OrbitControls unless required, as tree shaking works efficiently when you stick to ES6 import syntax
- Explicitly specify three as an external or vendor dependency in your webpack.config.js, or use resolve.alias to point directly to the node_modules/three/src/Three.js entry if tree-shaking is vital
- Activate sideEffects: false in your package.json or Webpack rules where practical for optimizing code elimination

## React Three Fiber Performance Recommendations

Even with React Three Fiber, performance best practices still apply—the abstraction should not become a crutch for ignoring optimisation.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about using `MeshTransmissionMaterial` with react-three-fiber for creating glass sphere effects:

## Overview

MeshTransmissionMaterial is an extension of the Three.js MeshPhysicalMaterial that adds properties like thickness, distortion and chromaticAberration. Although MeshTransmissionMaterial comes from Drei, Drei layers a bunch of shaders on top of Three.js' MeshPhysicalMaterial to create refraction effects.

## Key Properties

### Transmission & Roughness

The material acts like a normal PhysicalMaterial in terms of transmission support, thickness, ior, roughness, etc., but has chromatic aberration and noise-based roughness blur. When roughness is set to 1.0, the material becomes completely invisible because the surface becomes so rough that it scatters light completely, eliminating reflections while the material absorbs and diffuses all incoming light.

### Chromatic Aberration

The chromaticAberration field simulates color dispersion, where different wavelengths of light bend at slightly different angles, similar to how diamonds and prisms split light into a subtle rainbow effect. This field ranges from 0.0 to 1.0, with lower values resulting in little to no dispersion like real-life glass, and as the value approaches 1.0, color splitting becomes more pronounced.

## Code Example Structure

A typical implementation using `useControls` from leva includes properties like thickness (0.2-3), roughness (0-1), transmission (0-1), ior (0-3), chromaticAberration (0-1), and backside setting.

For practical implementation examples, you can refer to the official documentation at the React-Three-Drei repository and community tutorials that demonstrate applying this material to glass geometries like spheres and toruses.

I've successfully performed a web search for your query about Blender render paper pages transparent PNG floating documents for hero sections in web design. Here are the key findings:

## Rendering Transparent PNGs in Blender

**Basic Process:**
To create transparent backgrounds, check the "Transparent" box in the Film section, which ensures your world background will be transparent when the image is rendered. Set the File Format to PNG in Output Properties and make sure the Color is set to RGBA so the Alpha channel will be included in the output.

## Creating Realistic Paper Textures

Blender's robust shading system makes it surprisingly easy to simulate paper textures that read as tactile surfaces in 3D scenes, whether you're building a product mockup, book cover render, or packaging concept.

Begin with a simple plane or slightly curved panel to mimic a sheet of paper—the geometry doesn't need to be dense, just enough to support subtle bend and fold cues.

## Paper Characteristics to Model

Real paper has microscopic fibers, tiny color variations, and a characteristic diffuse glow when light passes through a thin sheet, with edges that reveal slightly different shading and catch light in a distinct way.

## Lighting Considerations

A checkerboard pattern in the background indicates transparency in the final rendered image. This approach is commonly used for hero section elements in web design where floating paper documents need clean, transparent backgrounds to overlay on website content.

## Spline's React Export Options

Spline allows you to export code as Vanilla JS, React, or Three.js. For React specifically, animations and events are only enabled when exporting to Vanilla JS and React.

## Integration with Three.js and react-three-fiber

r3f-spline is a React hook that lets you use your Spline scene with react-three-fiber. Additionally, the @splinetool/loader allows most Spline objects and materials to be rendered directly into three.js without a Spline runtime.

## Use Case Considerations

For rapid development with a focus on design, Spline offers a compelling solution, while react-three-fiber remains a solid choice for fine-grained control and performance optimization in complex 3D applications.

Links: [{"title":"SVG Filters 1.2, Part 2: Language","url":"https://www.w3.org/TR/SVGFilter12/"},{"title":"SVG filters · WebPlatform Docs","url":"https://webplatform.github.io/docs/svg/tutorials/smarter_svg_filters/"},{"title":"SVG Filters 101 | Codrops","url":"https://tympanus.net/codrops/2019/01/15/svg-filters-101/"},{"title":"Paper texture filter | Free SVG","url":"https://freesvg.org/kelan-paper-texture-filter"},{"title":"How to go beyond the basics with SVG filters | Creative Bloq","url":"https://www.creativebloq.REDACTED"},{"title":"SVG Filters to create organic paper textures within shapes. · GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/alexmwalker/b404eaa69c458076b7662ddb11fc244f"},{"title":"<feGaussianBlur> - SVG | MDN","url":"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/feGaussianBlur"},{"title":"Filter Effects in SVG: Dailey","url":"https://srufaculty.sru.edu/david.dailey/svg/SVGOpen2010/filters2.htm"},{"title":"A complete guide to using CSS filters with SVGs - LogRocket Blog","url":"https://blog.logrocket.com/complete-guide-using-css-filters-svgs/"},{"title":"SVG filter effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SVG_filter_effects"}]

I've completed the web search for your query about SVG filters for paper texture, grain, realistic shadows, and the specific filter primitives feGaussianBlur and feDropShadow.

Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Drop Shadow Effects

A generic drop shadow filter can be defined using feGaussianBlur with stdDeviation, feOffset, and feMerge elements. The feDropShadow primitive is a shorthand for a combination of other filter primitives, and the dx and dy attributes define the shadow's position along the x and y axis.

## Paper and Grain Textures

Filters can generate rich textures including brick, marble, felt, woven cloth, craft paper, sandpaper, film grain, earth and stucco. A rough paper texture can be created by generating a noise surface using the feTurbulence filter, then shining a light on that surface using a feDiffuseLighting effect, which creates subtle shadows.

Textures are generated using SVG's FETurbulence and FEDistortion filters and are automatically generated and layered over the original shape.

## Gaussian Blur

The feGaussianBlur SVG filter primitive blurs the input image by the amount specified in stdDeviation, which defines the bell-curve.

The search results include references to practical examples and documentation from official sources like the W3C SVG Filters specification, MDN, and various web development tutorials.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Atropos.js and 3D tilt card libraries:

## Atropos.js Overview

Atropos is a lightweight, free and open-source JavaScript library to create stunning touch-friendly 3D parallax hover effects. It's available for JavaScript, React and as WebComponent for use with Angular, Vue, Svelte, Solid and other frameworks.

## Key Features

Atropos applies interactive and touch-friendly 3D parallax hover effects to a group of images, based on Pointer Events and CSS3 transitions & transforms. The library provides various configuration options to customize the 3D parallax effect, including rotation angles, shadow settings, and callback functions.

## React Alternative Options

The search results mention several other lightweight 3D component libraries as alternatives:

- **Tilt.js**: A lightweight open-source JavaScript 3D library that adds dramatic tilting animations that work well on both desktop and mobile devices, without adding significant overhead to the web page.

- **Vanta.js**: Powered by three.js (using WebGL) or p5, it offers a diverse selection of pre-defined effects that can interact with mouse and touch inputs.

- **Zdog**: A 3D JavaScript engine library using canvas and SVG to design 3D models on web pages, providing a pseudo-3D engine to stimulate 3D objects and space while rendering them on a 2D canvas.

All of these libraries support React and offer lightweight solutions for adding interactive 3D effects to web components.

content.content:
# CSS 3D Sphere Techniques

Based on the article, here are the primary CSS methods for creating realistic spheres:

## Core Technique: Radial Gradients

The foundation uses `"radial-gradient(circle at 100px 100px, #5cabff, #000)"` to create basic shading. The gradient center position is offset from the element's center to simulate lighting.

## Layering with Pseudo-Elements

Multiple gradients combine via `:before` and `:after` selectors:

- **`:before`** - Creates underside lighting or base highlights using `"radial-gradient(circle at 50% 120%..."` positioned below the surface
- **`:after`** - Adds a sharp specular reflection with `"radial-gradient(circle at 50% 50%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.8)..."` then applies `transform: translateX(-80px) translateY(-90px) skewX(-20deg)`

## Key Effects

The article emphasizes using `filter: blur(5px)` to soften highlights and `transform` properties to skew reflections, making them appear as though reflecting off a curved surface rather than a flat one.

**Perspective setup**: The containing stage uses `"perspective: 1200px"` to establish a vanishing point, with shadows positioned via `transform: rotateX(90deg) translateZ(-150px)`.

The approach avoids photorealism by design, instead using carefully positioned gradients and blur effects to suggest 3D form on a single element.

I found relevant results about MeshPhysicalMaterial glass transmission with roughness and IOR in react-three-fiber contexts. Here are the key findings:

## Material Properties

MeshPhysicalMaterial includes properties that estimate refraction through transmissible objects: thickness, ior (Index-of-refraction) and reflectivity.

## Glass Effect Example

A practical example shows using MeshTransmissionMaterial with properties like thickness (0.2), roughness (0), transmission (1), ior (1.2), and chromaticAberration (0.02), which are commonly used values for creating glass-like effects.

## Roughness with Transmission

Using a small amount of roughness (0.05 – 0.15) can help soften aliasing on the transmitted content at the cost of a bit of sharpness. Additionally, when roughness is set to 1.0, the material becomes completely invisible because the surface becomes so rough that it scatters light completely.

## Glass Material Characteristics

A real glass material typically has a transmission of 1 and a roughness of 0.

## IOR (Index of Refraction)

IOR controls how much light bends when passing through a material, with lower IOR values resulting in less refraction, while higher IOR values increase distortion and depth, similar to glass or diamonds.

The search results include documentation from the react-three-drei library (which provides MeshTransmissionMaterial as an enhanced wrapper for MeshPhysicalMaterial) with full property specifications and usage examples.

content.content:
# MeshRefractionMaterial API Reference

## Overview
"A convincing Glass/Diamond refraction material" that simulates realistic light refraction through transparent objects like glass or diamonds.

## Type Definition

```typescript
type MeshRefractionMaterialProps = ThreeElements['shaderMaterial'] & {
  envMap: THREE.CubeTexture | THREE.Texture
  bounces?: number
  ior?: number
  fresnel?: number
  aberrationStrength?: number
  color?: ReactThreeFiber.Color
  fastChroma?: boolean
}
```

## Props Configuration

| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| `envMap` | CubeTexture \| Texture | Required | Environment map for reflections |
| `bounces` | number | 2 | "Number of ray-cast bounces, it can be expensive to have too many" |
| `ior` | number | 2.4 | Refraction index (higher = more bending) |
| `fresnel` | number | 0 | Strip light effect intensity |
| `aberrationStrength` | number | 0 | "RGB shift intensity, can be expensive" |
| `color` | Color | white | Material base color |
| `fastChroma` | boolean | true | "Uses fewer ray casts for RGB shift sacrificing physical accuracy" |

## Implementation Examples

### With CubeCamera (Reflects Scene Objects)

```jsx
<CubeCamera>
  {(texture) => (
    <mesh geometry={diamondGeometry} {...props}>
      <MeshRefractionMaterial envMap={texture} />
    </mesh>
  )}
</CubeCamera>
```

### With Environment Map

```jsx
const texture = useLoader(RGBELoader, "/textures/royal_esplanade_1k.hdr")
return (
  <mesh geometry={diamondGeometry} {...props}>
    <MeshRefractionMaterial envMap={texture} />
  </mesh>
)
```

## Source Location
`src/core/MeshRefractionMaterial.tsx`

Based on the search results, here's what I found about react-three-fiber floating paper pages animation in Next.js with performance considerations:

## Creating Floating Animations

You can create a 3D float effect using Three.js inside a Next.js application with React Three Fiber and Framer Motion. The Float utility function from react-three-drei provides a basic floating effect, and you can enhance the effect using Framer Motion to rotate and translate shapes on mouse move.

## Performance Considerations in Next.js

When integrating React Three Fiber with Next.js, there are several performance challenges to address:

- Integrating performance-intensive 3D scenes with Next.js involves ensuring 3D assets don't bloat initial page load, preventing hydration errors with complex canvas elements, and optimizing rendering performance for high-polygon models or intricate animations

## Optimization Strategies

You should try to re-use resources if you know they will repeat, as each geometry and material means additional overhead for the GPU. For complex scenes, you can half the resolution when the scene regresses, switch off lights when needed, use lower-res textures, or skip post-processing effects.

## Animation Libraries

For every R3F component, there's a motion equivalent from framer-motion-3d, supporting animation options including initial and animate props, exit and variants.

The search results provide several tutorial resources and documentation for implementing these effects with proper performance optimization.

I've successfully retrieved search results for CSS realistic paper texture grain noise background-image subtle fiber effects. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Main Approaches for Creating Paper Texture Effects

### 1. **SVG Filter Method (Most Popular)**
The trick is to use an SVG filter to create the noise, then apply that noise as a background. The feTurbulence filter is used, which generates Perlin or fractal noise. The SVG filter is then converted into a data URL and set as the background image of the card using the background-image CSS property with the url() function.

### 2. **Pure CSS Gradient Method (No Images)**
Paper fibers create a subtle "noise" pattern, and to replicate this, repeating linear gradients with tiny, random opacity variations are used. By leveraging CSS gradients, pseudo-elements, and clever styling, you can create a realistic old paper background without a single image, which is lightweight, fully customizable, and scalable.

### 3. **Opacity and Blending**
The opacity property is set to 0.1, which makes the grainy effect subtle. The CSS property mix-blend-mode can be used to smoothly blend gradients and mix-blend-mode allows blending with other gradients.

### 4. **Design Best Practices**
Select a paper texture that complements your design, with high-resolution textures adding realism and depth to enhance the overall user experience. Apply soft shadows to create a sense of depth, making the paper elements appear more lifelike and tactile.

You can find several online tools like **nnnoise** and **CSSmatic** that help generate these textures quickly for your projects.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about CSS multi-layer box-shadow techniques for creating realistic depth and soft shadow effects with ambient occlusion simulation:

## Core Technique

The key technique is layering: instead of using a single box-shadow, stack multiple shadows on top of each other with slightly-different offsets and radiuses to create more-realistic shadows.

## Multi-Layer Structure

Realistic shadows typically consist of three parts: an ambient shadow (a large, soft, low contrast blur that suggests room light), a key shadow (a smaller, darker blur that points away from the light source), and a contact shadow (a thin shadow right under the object, darkest near the contact point).

A single shadow rarely looks natural; real shadows are layered with a tight shadow near the object and softer ones farther away.

## Ambient Occlusion Simulation

A sharper, darker shadow close to the element can define its edge, while a softer, more diffuse, and lighter shadow can simulate ambient occlusion or light bounce. Smaller offset plus less blur creates a sharper contact shadow, while larger offset plus more blur creates ambient occlusion.

## Opacity Control

The key to realistic shadows is using multiple layers with proper opacity, as real shadows are complex with sharp edges close to objects and soft, diffused edges further away. You can let the alpha value decrease or increase with every layer to create more or less diffuse shadows, with the innermost shadow (least offset and blur) having the highest alpha value for concentrated shadows.

## Performance Considerations

Three layers per element is a good balance of quality and performance, and layered shadows are more expensive to render.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding react-three-fiber lazy loading, canvas progressive enhancement, and CSS fallbacks for 3D:

## Key Techniques for Lazy Loading & Progressive Enhancement

**React.lazy with Code Splitting:**
You can "lazy-load" the React component containing the @react-three-fiber import using React.lazy to delay the importing of a component until after the page has fully loaded.

**Suspense for Fallback Management:**
Suspense accepts a React component or null on the fallback prop, and renders its children when the initial page load is complete. Since model components are asynchronous, they should be nested within the Suspense component in the canvas, giving control over intermediate loading fallbacks and error handling.

**Progressive Loading Strategies:**
It is best to preload a minimal amount of assets needed for the player to start interacting and progressively preload whatever else you need before they need it. Using suspense works well as a fallback, however it can be jarring to see assets suddenly "pop in".

**CSS Fallbacks & HTML Enhancement:**
There's a tool called @14islands/r3f-scroll-rig that allows you to progressively enhance a React website with WebGL using @react-three/fiber. When adding 3D to your app, you should provide fallbacks for older devices as part of progressive enhancement.

**Performance Monitoring:**
Drei's PerformanceMonitor component collects average fps over time, and if averages are below or above a threshold it triggers callbacks that allow you to respond.

The search results show practical patterns for implementing lazy loading with CSS-based fallbacks, though explicit CSS fallback examples are limited in these results.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found regarding react-three-fiber with Next.js 15, "use client" directive, and dynamic imports:

## Key Compatibility Information

R3F v8 is not compatible with React 19 or Next 15. Use the R3F v9 RC instead which can be installed with @react-three/fiber@rc.

## Dynamic Import Pattern with SSR: False

Three.js relies on browser APIs that aren't available during server-side rendering. To avoid errors, you should use dynamic imports with the ssr option set to false:

```javascript
import dynamic from 'next/dynamic'
const Scene = dynamic(() => import('@/components/Scene'), { ssr: false })
```

## Client Component Setup

You can create a client component and then use everything inside there. Inside there you can use the same code as shown in the React Three Fiber docs, and the only thing that you need to change is that you put your jsx code inside your return function instead of the .render(...) function.

## Example Structure

For a Next.js 15 app router setup with "use client", your component structure would typically look like:

1. Create a client component with the "use client" directive
2. Use dynamic imports with `ssr: false` within the component
3. Place your Canvas and 3D content inside

The search results provide these patterns but don't contain a complete, fully worked-out 2025 example with all the modern best practices combined in a single code snippet.

I've found search results about CSS spheres and glass effects. Here are the key findings:

## Pure CSS Glass Sphere Resources

A CSS Spheres collection provides a complete guide to creating ultra-realistic three-dimensional sphere effects and complex geometry purely with CSS. These demonstrations show how to achieve depth and dynamic lighting without traditional 3D tools, using a combination of radial gradients, box-shadow, and CSS Houdini @property for smooth shadow animation.

One approach creates a realistic 3D sphere effect using pure CSS, without SVG or 3D transformations, achieved through gradients (radial-gradient), shadows (box-shadow), pseudo-elements (::before, ::after) for highlights and shadows, and dynamic variables (@property) for animation.

## Key Techniques

A realistic CSS sphere can be made using only one div and minimal CSS, creating a div that looks like a sphere using a radial gradient.

To create a more realistic looking ball, you can make it look like there are two light sources by using a pseudo-element to add two gradients.

## Glass Effect

For the glass appearance, the glass effect relies on a combination of CSS properties working together, with the backdrop-filter property applying blur to everything behind an element, creating that frosted appearance, and requiring rgba color values with reduced opacity for the background, typically between 0.1 and 0.3 alpha.

There's also a GitHub Gist specifically for a "Pure CSS glass sphere" available if you search directly for it.

I've completed the web search for your query about CSS perspective transforms. Here are the key findings:

## Key Resources Found:

**CSS 3D Transform Techniques:**
Examples demonstrating perspective effects include using `perspective` property, `transform-style: preserve-3d`, `rotateX` and `rotateY` transforms with layered `box-shadow` for depth.

**Paper/Page Tilt Effects:**
A stylish 3D book effect demonstrates interactive page-flipping (rotateY) on hover using `transform-style: preserve-3d` and shadows.

**Realistic Layered Shadows:**
To improve shadow realism, layering technique involves stacking multiple box-shadows on top of each other with slightly-different offsets and radiuses.

**Transform-Origin and Perspective-Origin:**
The `perspective-origin` property establishes the vanishing point's location in the scene - setting it to the left is as if the viewer stepped to the left, and setting it to the top is as if viewing the object from a higher standpoint.

**CodePen Examples:**
Several CodePen demonstrations exist showing "3D shadow hover," "3D text plus tilt on hover," and "3D image tilt with CSS" using perspective and rotation properties.

The search results contain multiple practical examples combining perspective, transform-origin, rotation angles, and layered shadow techniques for creating realistic 3D paper/page tilt effects.

Based on the search results, here's information about creating pre-rendered 3D glass sphere PNG images with transparent backgrounds in Blender for web hero sections:

## Basic Transparent Background Setup

In principle, rendering images with transparency in Blender is simple – you navigate to the Properties Panel, under the Render Properties tab, and go to the Film section and check the box for Transparent.

## Export Settings for PNG

Make sure File Format is set to PNG, and check that Color is set to RGBA (otherwise the Alpha channel won't be included). The extra "A" stands for Alpha, which keeps the transparency information.

## Rendering Glass with Transparency

When creating renders with transparent backgrounds, an important consideration is any objects in your scene that are themselves transparent, such as glass. Your options for rendering glass in Blender will be different depending on whether you're using Cycles or Eevee. In Cycles, after enabling Transparent under Film, you are also given the option to enable Transparent Glass.

## Animation/Sequence Export

For web hero sections with animated elements, the best way to export video in Blender isn't as a video file but as an Image Sequence, and as long as either PNG or OpenEXR formats are used, transparency is fully supported.

This approach allows you to create professional 3D glass sphere assets with transparent backgrounds that can be easily integrated into web designs and hero sections.

I've completed the web search for your query. Here are the key findings comparing pre-rendered 3D assets (PNG) in hero sections versus real-time WebGL performance:

## Key Differences

**Pre-Rendered Assets (PNG/Static Images):**
- Pre-rendered assets are perfect for static hero images, social media ads, and product thumbnails.
- Pre-rendered visuals generally boast higher quality, as there are no constraints on lighting calculations, resolution, or processing time.
- Pre-rendered sequences are often larger in file size, especially in video format.

**Real-Time WebGL:**
- WebGL allows for real-time rendering, enabling interactive experiences where users can manipulate objects or scenes dynamically.
- Real-time graphics demand more powerful GPUs to maintain smooth performance, while pre-rendered scenes can be created on powerful workstations but played back on modest devices.

## Performance Considerations

Achieving high-quality visuals in real time requires powerful hardware, and artists must often optimize assets to maintain performance, which can compromise visual fidelity compared to pre-rendered counterparts.

## Practical Recommendations

Use pre-rendering for hero images and social media content. Use real-time rendering for product configurators, AR previews, and interactive experiences.

The search results indicate that pre-rendered PNGs for hero sections offer better visual quality and broader device compatibility, while WebGL shines when interactivity and user engagement are priorities.

Based on the web search results, here are the key findings about react-three-fiber, Next.js 15 app router, and bundle size performance:

## Bundle Size and Performance Impact

Three.js doesn't really tree-shake, though you can avoid a few kilobytes still. This is a fundamental limitation when using react-three-fiber, as Three.js typically has a gzip size of around 155 KB.

## Integration with Next.js 15 App Router

Integrating react-three-fiber into Next.js with the App Router presents challenges including ensuring 3D assets don't bloat page load, managing server and client components coexistence, preventing hydration errors with complex canvas elements, and optimizing rendering performance with high-polygon models.

React Three Fiber should work out of the box with Next.js, though you may need to add three to the transpilePackages property in next.config.js for untranspiled add-ons in the three.js ecosystem.

## Optimization Strategies

If you're using App Router properly, you can legitimately ship production pages with 50–80KB of JavaScript. The key appears to be architectural decisions: placing 'use client' in the right place is more impactful than bundle configuration tweaking.

For performance, the react-three-next starter uses gl.scissor to cut the viewport into segments for better performance.

### Next.js 13.1+ Configuration for Three.js Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber/blob/master/docs/getting-started/installation.mdx Configures Next.js 13.1 or later to transpile the 'three' package by adding it to the 'transpilePackages' array in next.config.js. This is necessary for using Three.js within Next.js. ```javascript /** @type {import('next').NextConfig} */ const nextConfig = { transpilePackages: ['three'], } module.exports = nextConfig ``` -------------------------------- ### Initialize a React Three Fiber Scene with Canvas Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber/blob/master/docs/API/canvas.mdx This snippet demonstrates the basic setup of a 3D scene using the Canvas component. It imports necessary modules and renders a simple scene with a point light and a mesh. This is the foundational step for any React Three Fiber application. ```jsx import React from 'react' import { Canvas } from '@react-three/fiber' const App = () => ( ) ``` -------------------------------- ### Initialize 3D Scene with Canvas Component (React JSX) Source: https://context7.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber/llms.txt The Canvas component is the entry point for creating a 3D scene. It sets up the Three.js scene, camera, renderer, and render loop. It accepts various props for configuration, including camera settings, shadow quality, device pixel ratio, WebGL context options, and event handlers. ```jsx import { Canvas } from '@react-three/fiber' function App() { return ( console.log('Canvas ready', state)} onPointerMissed={() => console.log('Clicked outside any mesh')} > ) } ``` -------------------------------- ### Setup React Three Fiber Canvas Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber/blob/master/docs/getting-started/your-first-scene.mdx Initializes the React application and renders the Canvas component from '@react-three/fiber'. This component sets up the Three.js Scene and Camera automatically. The Canvas's size is determined by its parent container. ```jsx import { createRoot } from 'react-dom/client' import { Canvas } from '@react-three/fiber' function App() { return (
) } createRoot(document.getElementById('root')).render() ``` -------------------------------- ### Install React Three Fiber with npm/yarn Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber/blob/master/docs/getting-started/installation.mdx Installs the core react-three-fiber and three.js libraries using npm or yarn. This is the fundamental step for integrating R3F into your project. ```bash npm install three @react-three/fiber ``` ```bash yarn add three @react-three/fiber ```

content.content:
# Layered Box-Shadow Technique for Smoother Shadows

The core technique involves stacking multiple `box-shadow` declarations with progressively increasing offset and blur values:

## Basic Smooth Shadow Example
```css
.shadow-5 {
  box-shadow: 0 1px 1px rgba(0,0,0,0.12), 
              0 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0,0.12), 
              0 4px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.12), 
              0 8px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.12),
              0 16px 16px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
}
```

## Key Variations

**Sharp Shadows** (decreasing alpha):
```css
.shadow-sharp {
  box-shadow: 0 1px 1px rgba(0,0,0,0.25), 
              0 2px 2px rgba(0,0,0,0.20), 
              0 4px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.15), 
              0 8px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.10),
              0 16px 16px rgba(0,0,0,0.05);
}
```

**Soft Shadows** (increasing alpha and blur):
```css
.shadow-dreamy {
    box-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,0.07), 
                0 2px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.07), 
                0 4px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.07), 
                0 8px 16px rgba(0,0,0,0.07),
                0 16px 32px rgba(0,0,0,0.07), 
                0 32px 64px rgba(0,0,0,0.07);
}
```

The technique allows fine-tuning of sharpness, distance, and spread through alpha values and blur radius manipulation.

content.content:
# CSS Techniques for Realistic Layered Shadows

## Multi-Layer Box-Shadow Technique

The primary method involves stacking multiple shadows with progressively larger offsets and blur radii:

```css
.layered.box {
  box-shadow:
    0 1px 1px hsl(0deg 0% 0% / 0.075),
    0 2px 2px hsl(0deg 0% 0% / 0.075),
    0 4px 4px hsl(0deg 0% 0% / 0.075),
    0 8px 8px hsl(0deg 0% 0% / 0.075),
    0 16px 16px hsl(0deg 0% 0% / 0.075);
}
```

This approach creates subtlety by "layering multiple shadows with slightly-different offsets and radiuses."

## Key Principles for Photorealistic Shadows

**Consistent Light Source:** "Every shadow on the page should share the same ratio" between horizontal and vertical offsets to simulate unified lighting.

**Elevation Scaling:** As elements rise, three properties must increase together:
- Offset distance increases
- Blur radius expands
- Opacity decreases

## Color-Matched Shadows

Rather than pure black, match the background's hue while reducing saturation and lightness:

```css
.box {
  box-shadow: 1px 2px 8px hsl(220deg 60% 50%);
}
```

This prevents the "washed-out" gray appearance of transparent black shadows layered over colored backgrounds.

## Performance Consideration

"Layered shadows don't affect performance in a significant way" on modern hardware, though older mobile devices may experience slowdown with excessive layering.

content.content:
# MeshTransmissionMaterial API Reference

## Overview
An enhanced THREE.MeshPhysicalMaterial with chromatic aberration, noise-based roughness blur, anisotropic blur support, and the ability to see other transmissive/transparent objects for improved visuals.

## Type Definition
```typescript
type MeshTransmissionMaterialProps = ThreeElements['meshPhysicalMaterial'] & {
  transmission?: number
  thickness?: number
  backsideThickness?: number
  roughness?: number
  chromaticAberration?: number
  anisotropicBlur?: number
  distortion?: number
  distortionScale?: number
  temporalDistortion?: number
  buffer?: THREE.Texture
  transmissionSampler?: boolean
  backside?: boolean
  resolution?: number
  backsideResolution?: number
  samples?: number
  background?: THREE.Texture
}
```

## Props & Defaults

| Prop | Default | Purpose |
|------|---------|---------|
| `transmission` | 1 | Material transparency level |
| `thickness` | 0 | Refraction depth |
| `backsideThickness` | 0 | Backface refraction depth |
| `roughness` | 0 | Surface blur intensity |
| `chromaticAberration` | 0.03 | Color separation effect |
| `anisotropicBlur` | 0.1 | Directional blur support |
| `distortion` | 0 | Surface distortion amount |
| `distortionScale` | 0.5 | Distortion scaling factor |
| `temporalDistortion` | 0.0 | Animation speed for distortion |
| `samples` | 6 | Refraction quality |
| `resolution` | undefined | Buffer pixel size (fullscreen if unset) |
| `backsideResolution` | undefined | Backface buffer size |
| `backside` | false | Render backside (increased cost) |
| `buffer` | null | Shared texture reference |
| `transmissionSampler` | false | Use THREE.js internal buffer |
| `background` | null | Buffer scene background |

## Usage Examples

### Basic Implementation
```jsx
<mesh geometry={geometry}>
  <MeshTransmissionMaterial />
</mesh>
```

### Shared Buffer with useFBO
```jsx
const buffer = useFBO()
useFrame((state) => {
  state.gl.setRenderTarget(buffer)
  state.gl.render(state.scene, state.camera)
  state.gl.setRenderTarget(null)
})
return (
  <>
    <mesh geometry={torus}>
      <MeshTransmissionMaterial buffer={buffer.texture} />
    </mesh>
  </>
)
```

### Using PerspectiveCamera
```jsx
<PerspectiveCamera makeDefault fov={75} position={[10, 0, 15]}>
  {(texture) => (
    <mesh geometry={torus}>
      <MeshTransmissionMaterial buffer={texture} />
    </mesh>
  )}
</PerspectiveCamera>
```

## Performance Optimization Tips

- **Roughness**: Use tiny resolutions (32x32 pixels) for blurred effects while maintaining visual quality
- **Multiple Materials**: Enable `transmissionSampler` to share buffers across materials, though materials won't see each other
- **Sample Count**: Lower sample values improve performance at the cost of visual fidelity
- **Host Mesh Visibility**: The mesh temporarily hides during rendering passes; child objects remain visible unless explicitly excluded

## Key Behaviors

- Host mesh is temporarily removed from render stack during buffer generation
- Child meshes of the host remain visible in the transmission texture
- Unlike standard MeshPhysicalMaterial, this implementation can reflect other transmissive/transparent objects

content.content:
# Grainy Gradients: SVG Noise Texture Technique

## SVG feTurbulence Filter Code

The core technique uses an SVG filter with Perlin noise generation:

```xml
<svg viewBox="0 0 200 200" xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'>
  <filter id='noiseFilter'>
    <feTurbulence 
      type='fractalNoise' 
      baseFrequency='0.65' 
      numOctaves='3' 
      stitchTiles='stitch' />
  </filter>
  <rect width='100%' height='100%' filter='url(#noiseFilter)' />
</svg>
```

**Key attributes:**
- `type='fractalNoise'` - Creates natural-looking Perlin noise
- `baseFrequency` - Controls texture coarseness (adjust 0.65 for finer/coarser grain)
- `numOctaves` - Determines complexity levels
- `stitchTiles='stitch'` - Enables seamless tiling

## Applying as CSS Background

Layer the SVG with a gradient and enhance visibility:

```css
.noise {
  background:
    linear-gradient(to right, blue, transparent),
    url(noise.svg);
  filter: contrast(170%) brightness(1000%);
}
```

The article explains: "Boosting brightness and contrast pushes out the muddled grays," making the texture more pronounced. Reference the SVG externally or inline it directly in CSS for best results.

## Optional: CSS Blending

For refined color control, stack additional layers with `mix-blend-mode`:

```css
.overlay {
  mix-blend-mode: multiply;
  background: moccasin;
}
```

This technique works across modern browsers but not Internet Explorer.

content.text:
### Float Component Usage - JavaScript

Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/blob/master/docs/staging/float.mdx

Demonstrates the basic usage of the Float component with customizable animation parameters. It shows how to control speed, rotation intensity, float intensity, and the floating range for a child mesh. Defaults are provided for each parameter.

```javascript
<Float
  speed={1} // Animation speed, defaults to 1
  rotationIntensity={1} // XYZ rotation intensity, defaults to 1
  floatIntensity={1} // Up/down float intensity, works like a multiplier with floatingRange,defaults to 1
  floatingRange={[1, 10]} // Range of y-axis values the object will float within, defaults to [-0.1,0.1]
>
  <mesh />
</Float>
```

--------------------------------

### Float Animation with React Three Fiber

Source: https://context7.com/pmndrs/drei/llms.txt

The Float component adds a subtle floating or hovering animation to its children. It offers configurable parameters for speed, rotation intensity, and float intensity, making it ideal for UI elements or ambient motion. It requires '@react-three/fiber' and '@react-three/drei'.

```jsx
import { Canvas } from '@react-three/fiber'
import { Float, Text, OrbitControls } from '@react-three/drei'

function App() {
  return (
    <Canvas>
      {/* Basic floating */}
      <Float>
        <mesh>
          <boxGeometry />
          <meshStandardMaterial color="hotpink" />
        </mesh>
      </Float>

      {/* Configured float */}
      <Float
        speed={2}
        rotationIntensity={0.5}
        floatIntensity={2}
        floatingRange={[-0.2, 0.2]}
      >
        <mesh position={[2, 0, 0]}>
          <sphereGeometry />
          <meshStandardMaterial color="royalblue" />
        </mesh>
      </Float>

      {/* Floating text */}
      <Float speed={1.5} floatIntensity={1}>
        <Text fontSize={0.5} color="white">
          Floating Text
        </Text>
      </Float>

      {/* For demand frameloop */}
      <Float autoInvalidate>
        <mesh position={[-2, 0, 0]}>
          <torusGeometry args={[0.5, 0.2, 16, 32]} />
          <meshStandardMaterial color="orange" />
        </mesh>
      </Float>

      <OrbitControls />
      <ambientLight intensity={0.5} />
      <directionalLight position={[5, 5, 5]} />
    </Canvas>
  )
}
```

--------------------------------

### Image Component with Custom Rounded Plane Geometry (JSX)

Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/blob/master/docs/abstractions/image.mdx

Illustrates how to use a custom rounded plane geometry with the Image component. This involves extending the geometry in @react-three/fiber and providing the custom geometry as a child to the Image component.

```jsx
import { extend } from '@react-three/fiber'
import { Image } from '@react-three/drei'
import { easing, geometry } from 'maath'

extend({ RoundedPlaneGeometry: geometry.RoundedPlaneGeometry })

<Image url="/file.jpg">
  <roundedPlaneGeometry args={[1, 2, 0.15]} />
</Image>
```

--------------------------------

### Basic SpriteAnimator Usage (JSX)

Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/blob/master/docs/misc/sprite-animator.mdx

Demonstrates a fundamental implementation of the SpriteAnimator component using basic props like `numberOfFrames`, `textureImageURL`, and animation control flags. This example is suitable for simple spritesheets without JSON data.

```jsx
<SpriteAnimator
  position={[-3.5, -2.0, 2.5]}
  startFrame={0}
  meshProps={{ frustumCulled: false, scale: 2.5 }}
  autoPlay={true}
  loop={true}
  numberOfFrames={16}
  textureImageURL={'./alien.png'}
/>
```

--------------------------------

### ScrollControls and SpriteAnimator Setup with React

Source: https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/blob/master/docs/misc/sprite-animator.mdx

This snippet sets up the ScrollControls component to define scrollable pages and integrates SpriteAnimator for playing sprite animations. It passes configuration options like damping, maxSpeed, and pages to ScrollControls, and texture URLs, animation frames, and event handlers to SpriteAnimator. The FireScroll component is nested within SpriteAnimator.

```jsx
<ScrollControls damping={0.2} maxSpeed={0.5} pages={2}>
  <SpriteAnimator
    position={[0.0, -1.5, -1.5]}
    startFrame={0}
```

Based on the search results, here's what I found about creating a glass sphere with React Three Fiber using `MeshTransmissionMaterial`:

## Key Resources Found

The React Three Drei package includes a community-made `MeshTransmissionMaterial` that provides transparency and distortion out of the box. It's an extension of Three.js's `MeshPhysicalMaterial` that adds properties like thickness, distortion, and chromatic aberration.

## Basic Sphere Structure

In React Three Fiber, you can create a sphere using declarative JSX with `sphereGeometry` and passing constructor arguments via the `args` prop:

```jsx
<mesh>
  <sphereGeometry args={[1, 16, 16]} />
  <meshStandardMaterial color="hotpink" transparent />
</mesh>
```

## Glass Material Implementation

To create glass, you can modify a mesh by adding a `MeshTransmissionMaterial` as a child to achieve glass aesthetics, which removes the need for the existing material.

A typical implementation would look like:

```jsx
import { MeshTransmissionMaterial } from '@react-three/drei'

function GlassSphere() {
  return (
    <mesh>
      <sphereGeometry args={[1, 32, 32]} />
      <MeshTransmissionMaterial 
        thickness={1}
        distortion={0.5}
        chromaticAberration={0.5}
      />
    </mesh>
  )
}
```

For a complete hero landing page example, you would wrap this in a Canvas with appropriate lighting and environment setup, though the search results don't contain a full, ready-to-use complete example code. I'd recommend checking the official React Three Fiber and @react-three/drei documentation for the latest examples and implementation details.

content.content:
# 3D Glass Effect Implementation Guide

Based on the tutorial, here's how to create a glass material with distortion:

## Key Components

**Scene Setup (Scene.jsx):**
The tutorial establishes a Canvas with lighting and environment:
```
<Canvas> with directionalLight and Environment preset
```

**Material Configuration:**
The implementation uses `MeshTransmissionMaterial` from React Three Drei, which extends Three.js's MeshPhysicalMaterial. According to the guide, this material "gives us everything we need out of the box" by supporting "transmission but adds on top of it multiple other properties like thickness, distortion and chromaticAberration."

## Material Properties

The tutorial demonstrates using `leva` for interactive controls:

- **thickness**: Range 0-3 (default 0.2) - controls glass depth perception
- **roughness**: Range 0-1 (default 0) - surface smoothness
- **transmission**: Range 0-1 (default 1) - transparency level
- **ior**: Range 0-3 (default 1.2) - refractive index
- **chromaticAberration**: Range 0-1 (default 0.02) - color separation effect
- **backside**: Boolean (default true) - renders material on back faces

## Implementation Pattern

The mesh receives the material configuration via props, enabling "a realistic glass effect" through these combined properties working together.

The tutorial emphasizes that "MeshTransmissionMaterial...really help give a realistic glass effect" when applied to 3D geometry imported from .GLB files.

content.content:
# React-Three-Fiber Setup Guide for Next.js 15

## Core Issue

The primary challenge is a **version incompatibility**. As stated in the official documentation: "R3F v8 is not compatible with React 19 or Next 15, which uses React 19. Use the R3F v9 RC instead."

## Installation

Install the RC version compatible with React 19:
```bash
npm install @react-three/fiber@rc
```

Alternatively, downgrade to React 18 if you prefer the stable v8 release.

## Implementation Pattern

### 1. Create a Client Component
Mark your Three.js component with the `'use client'` directive at the top of the file, since Three.js rendering requires browser APIs that aren't available during server-side rendering.

### 2. Dynamic Import with SSR Disabled
Wrap your Three.js component in Next.js's `dynamic` import to skip server-side rendering:

```typescript
import dynamic from 'next/dynamic';

const ThreeComponent = dynamic(
  () => import('../components/YourThreeComponent'),
  { ssr: false }
);
```

### 3. Basic Component Structure
Place your Three.js code inside the component's return function rather than using the traditional `.render()` pattern. Reference the [official R3F documentation](https://r3f.docs.pmnd.rs/getting-started/introduction) for element syntax.

## Key Configuration Details

- Use `'use client'` directive in your Three.js component file
- Apply `{ ssr: false }` option when dynamically importing
- Ensure you're using R3F v9 RC or later with Next.js 15
- Standard JSX intrinsic elements like `<mesh>` become available once proper versions are installed

This resolves TypeScript errors like "Property 'mesh' does not exist on type 'JSX.IntrinsicElements'."

content.content:
# 3D Float Effect Implementation Guide

## Canvas & Environment Setup

The foundation uses React Three Fiber with an orthographic camera to flatten perspective. The implementation initializes: `<Canvas style={{background: "#e0e0e2"}} orthographic camera={{position: [0, 0, 200], zoom: 10}}>` with a studio environment preset for consistent lighting.

## Model & Geometry Extraction

Models are exported as GLB files from 3D software (like Blender), then loaded via `useGLTF` hook from React Three Drei. This utility extracts all node geometry, materials, positions, scales, and rotations automatically, eliminating manual mesh configuration.

## Float Animation Layer

The `Float` component from React Three Drei provides the base floating motion. As noted in the tutorial: *"To add a basic float effect, it's actually very easy with the help of a utilitory function called Float from react-three-drei."* This wraps the mesh group and applies natural bobbing animation.

## Mouse-Driven Enhancement

Framer Motion transforms mouse coordinates into 3D transformations:

- **Position tracking**: Mouse coordinates (0-1 range) map to position offsets on X and Y axes
- **Rotation mapping**: Mouse movement influences rotationX and rotationY values
- **Smoothing**: `useSpring` hook dampens raw mouse events for fluid motion

Each mesh receives a multiplier variable controlling the intensity of these transformations, creating parallax depth.

## Shadow & Material Rendering

Meshes include `castShadow` and `receiveShadow` properties enabled, allowing realistic shadow interaction. The studio environment preset handles ambient and directional lighting automatically.

content.content:
# Physics-Based 3D Cloth Implementation: Key Details

## Core Architecture

The simulation uses a **soft body approach** rather than rigid bodies. Each mesh vertex becomes an independent physics particle connected to neighbors via constraints, creating cloth-like behavior.

### Particle Creation
"We don't want a sphere nor a cube for each point of our cloth. Cannon provides the Particle() object, a shape with ... no shape at all!" Each vertex gets its own body with mass distributed across all particles: `mass / position.count`.

### Constraint System
Particles connect through distance constraints between adjacent vertices:
- Horizontal connections: `connect(i, i + 1)`
- Vertical connections: `connect(i, i + size + 1)`

This creates a grid structure where fabric behavior emerges from constraint propagation.

## Control Parameters

**Stiffness & Damping:**
- `linearDamping: 0.8` prevents infinite motion oscillation
- Distance constraints naturally resist stretching between particles
- Gravity: `world.gravity.set(0, -1000, 0)` scaled for object size

**Fixed Points:**
First row of particles use `mass: 0`, anchoring the cloth from the top and enabling draping effects.

## Wind Effect Integration

Simplex noise generates spatially-varying force fields. For each particle: `force = noise3D(row * offset, col * offset, time) * strength`

This creates organic, flowing disturbances rather than uniform wind, with directional control mapped to mouse position via GSAP animation.

## Position Synchronization

Each frame updates mesh vertices from physics bodies, converting normalized Three.js coordinates back to world space using stored mesh dimensions.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Apple's Liquid Glass CSS effect:

## Overview

Liquid Glass is a modern UI pattern introduced in iOS 26 that extends Glassmorphism with more physically plausible optical effects. Apple introduced this new design language at WWDC 2025.

## Technical Implementation

Liquid Glass adds light bending on curved edges, localized distortion, and specular highlights that respond to context, with widgets and buttons appearing to bend and distort the background along their edges, similar to how real glass or fluid materials behave.

The effect is built using CSS techniques: These examples utilize backdrop-filter for real-time background blurring and mask-image to define shifting boundaries, and combine mix-blend-mode with SVG displacement maps to simulate realistic light refraction and surface tension.

## Creating the Effect

A high-fidelity recreation of Apple's Liquid Glass effect uses CSS backdrop-filter and advanced SVG filters, featuring feDisplacementMap and feSpecularLighting to achieve realistic glass distortion and light refraction seen in premium macOS-style UI designs.

## Current Resources

There are numerous tools and generators available for creating these effects, including free CSS generators and open-source projects on GitHub that allow developers to build Apple-style liquid glass UI effects for web and mobile applications.

Links: [{"title":"Simplifying 3D Integration in React: Spline vs. react-three-fiber | by Akbarjason | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@akbar123jason/simplifying-3d-integration-in-react-spline-vs-react-three-fiber-3f5e1a9e39d3"},{"title":"React-Three-Fiber vs. Spline | Needle","url":"https://cloud.needle.tools/compare/needle-vs-r3f-vs-spline"},{"title":"GitHub - splinetool/r3f-spline: Hook to load Spline scenes into react-three-fiber","url":"https://github.com/splinetool/r3f-spline"},{"title":"What are React and React Three Fiber — Three.js Journey","url":"https://threejs-journey.com/lessons/what-are-react-and-react-three-fiber"},{"title":"React-spline Overview, Examples, Pros and Cons in 2025","url":"https://best-of-web.builder.io/library/splinetool/react-spline"},{"title":"Scaling performance - React Three Fiber","url":"https://r3f.docs.pmnd.rs/advanced/scaling-performance"},{"title":"react-three-fiber vs three.js | What are the differences?","url":"https://stackshare.io/stackups/react-three-fiber-vs-three-js"},{"title":"How to make Remix 2 work with @react-three/fiber? · remix-run/remix · Discussion #8255","url":"https://github.com/remix-run/remix/discussions/8255"},{"title":"Spline | Three.js Resources","url":"https://threejsresources.com/tool/spline"},{"title":"Optimizing Performance | splinetool/react-spline | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/splinetool/react-spline/5.2-optimizing-performance"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comparison of Spline design vs react-three-fiber for performance, bundle size, and loading time:

## Performance and Use Cases

For rapid development with a focus on design, Spline offers a compelling solution, while react-three-fiber remains a solid choice for fine-grained control and performance optimization in complex 3D applications.

## Bundle Size and Loading Time

React-three-fiber requires more manual setup and configuration and performance may be less optimized for simpler scenes compared to react-spline. However, while react-three-fiber increases the overall bundle size and can affect the initial loading time of the application, three.js is a standalone library with a smaller bundle size and faster loading time.

## Flexibility and Control

React-three-fiber offers more granular control over scene elements, while react-spline provides a simpler API for importing pre-designed Spline scenes. React-three-fiber is better suited for developers who need full control over their 3D environments, while react-spline is ideal for quickly integrating ready-made 3D designs into React applications.

## Performance Optimization Features

For react-three-fiber, on-demand rendering is available, which will only render when necessary. For react-spline, performance optimization involves using built-in features effectively (render-on-demand, responsive handling, lazy loading) and following best practices for 3D web content to create smooth, responsive 3D experiences even in complex React applications.

In summary: **Spline** is better for quick design-focused implementations with simpler performance characteristics, while **react-three-fiber** offers more control and optimization options for complex 3D scenes, though it comes with a larger bundle size overhead.
